mechanic.eng_def: someone whose job is repairing the engines of vehicles and other machines
the study of the effect of physical forces on objects and their movement
the way something works or happens
mechanic.eg: He knows a lot about the mechanics of running a school.

mechanical.eng_def: operated by a machine, or connected with machines or their parts
relating to movement, or to mechanics (= the study of the effect of physical forces on objects and their movement)
mechanical.eg: a study of the effects of mechanical forces on bones

mechanical.eng_def: without thinking about what you are doing, especially because you do something often

mechanics.eng_def: someone whose job is repairing the engines of vehicles and other machines
the study of the effect of physical forces on objects and their movement
the way something works or happens
mechanics.eg: He knows a lot about the mechanics of running a school.

mechanism.eng_def: a part of a machine, or a set of parts that work together
mechanism.eg: These automatic cameras have a special focusing mechanism.

mechanism.eng_def: a way of doing something that is planned or part of a system
mechanism.eg: The mechanism for collecting taxes needs revising.

mechanism.eng_def: a part of your behaviour that helps you to deal with a difficult situation
mechanism.eg: She's actually kind of insecure, and her rudeness is just a defence mechanism.

medal.eng_def: a small metal disc, with words or a picture on it, given as a reward for a brave action, for winning a competition, or to remember a special event
medal.eg: He was awarded a medal for bravery.

medal.eng_def: to win a medal in a sports competition
medal.eg: She medalled in both the heptathlon and the long jump.

media.eng_def: the internet, newspapers, magazines, television, etc., considered as a group

mediate.eng_def: to talk to two separate people or groups involved in a disagreement to try to help them to agree or find a solution to their problems
mediate.eg: Negotiators were called in to mediate between the two sides.

medical.eng_def: related to the treatment of illness and injuries
an examination of a person's body by a doctor in order to discover if that person is healthy, sometimes done before a person can be accepted for a particular job
medical.eg: The insurance company wanted me to have a medical.

medication.eng_def: a medicine, or a set of medicines or drugs, used to improve a particular condition or illness
medication.eg: He is currently on/taking medication for his heart.

medicine.eng_def: treatment for illness or injury, or the study of this
a substance, especially in the form of a liquid or a pill, that is a treatment for illness or injury

medieval.eng_def: related to the Middle Ages (= the period in European history from about AD 600 to AD 1500)
medieval.chi_def: 中世紀（約西元600年至1500年間）的，中古時代的

meditate.eng_def: to think calm thoughts in order to relax or as a religious activity
meditate.eg: Sophie meditates for 20 minutes every day.

meditate.eng_def: to think seriously about something for a long time
meditate.eg: He meditated on the consequences of his decision.

meditation.eng_def: the act of giving your attention to only one thing, either as a religious activity or as a way of becoming calm and relaxed
serious thought or study, or the product of this activity
meditation.eg: Let us spend a few moments in quiet meditation.

medium.eng_def: being in the middle between an upper and lower amount, size, degree, or value
(of meat) cooked so that it is no longer red in the middle
medium.eg: Would you like your steak rare, medium, or well done?

medium.eng_def: a method or way of expressing something
a person who says that they can receive messages from people who are dead
a substance that something grows in, lives in, or moves through
medium.eg: Compost is an excellent growing medium.

meet.eng_def: to see and talk to someone for the first time
to come together with someone intentionally
meet.eg: Lorraine and I meet for lunch once a month.

meet.eng_def: to come together with someone without intending to
meet.eg: It's always awkward when you meet someone you know but you can't remember their name.
The workers' demands for higher pay were not met by the management.
The company has agreed to meet all our expenses.

meet.eng_def: to wait at a place for someone or something to arrive
meet.eg: Will you meet me at the airport (= be there when the aircraft arrives)?
There's a large crack where the ceiling meets the wall.
I've never met that kind of problem/system before.

meet.eng_def: an occasion when people go fox hunting

meeting.eng_def: a planned occasion when people come together to discuss something
meeting.eg: We're having a meeting on Thursday to discuss the problem.

meeting.eng_def: an occasion when people meet each other, especially when this was not planned
meeting.chi_def: （尤指事先未安排的）會面，見面
meeting.eg: A chance (= not intended) meeting with a publisher on an airplane had launched his career.

meeting.eng_def: a group of people who have met for a particular purpose
meeting.eg: The meeting wants to look at the proposal again.

melancholy.eng_def: sadness that lasts for a long period of time, often without any obvious reason

mellow.eng_def: smooth and soft, or not too sharp, bright, new, or rough
relaxed and pleasant or not severe
to become softer and more developed in a pleasing way
mellow.eg: The brickwork will mellow over the years so that it blends with the surroundings.
She used to be very impatient, but she's mellowed over time.

melody.eng_def: a tune, often forming part of a larger piece of music
melody.eg: He played a few well-known melodies.

melon.eng_def: a large, round fruit with hard yellow or green skin, sweet flesh, and a lot of seeds

melt.eng_def: to turn from something solid into something soft or liquid, or to cause something to do this
melt.eg: The snow usually melts by mid March.

melt.eng_def: to start to feel love or sympathy, especially after feeling angry
melt.eg: He only has to look at her, and she melts.

melt.chi_def: （塗有融化了的起司的）三明治

member.eng_def: a person, animal, or thing that is part of a group
a person who joins a group to take part in a particular activity

membership.eng_def: the state of belonging to an organization
membership.chi_def: 會員資格，會員身份，會籍
membership.eg: You have to apply for membership of the sports club.

membership.eng_def: all the people who belong to an organization
membership.eg: Our membership is/are divided on the issue.

memorable.eng_def: likely to be remembered or worth remembering

memorial.eng_def: an object, often large and made of stone, that has been built to honour a famous person or event
done to remember a person or people who have died
memorial.chi_def: 用以紀念的，紀念性的；追悼的
memorial.eg: Hundreds of people came to Professor Conner's memorial service.

memorize.eng_def: to learn something so that you will remember it exactly
memorize.eg: When I was at school, we were required to memorize a poem every week.

memory.eng_def: the ability to remember information, experiences, and people
something that you remember from the past
memory.eg: I have vivid memories of that evening.

memory.eng_def: the part of a computer in which information or programs are stored either permanently or temporarily, or the amount of space available on it for storing information
memory.eg: My computer has a gigabyte of memory.

menace.eng_def: something that is likely to cause harm
menace.chi_def: 危險的事物；構成威脅的事物
menace.eg: Drunk drivers are a menace to everyone.

menace.eng_def: a dangerous quality that makes you think someone is going to do something bad
menace.eg: He had a slight air of menace which made me uneasy.

menace.eng_def: a person, especially a child, who is very annoying

menace.eg: He was accused of unlawfully demanding money with menaces.

menace.eng_def: If someone or something menaces a person or thing, he, she, or it threatens seriously to harm it.
menace.eg: Hurricane Hugo menaced the eastern coast for a week.

mend.eng_def: to repair something that is broken or damaged
mend.eg: Could you mend this hole in my shirt?

mend.eng_def: a place in a piece of clothing where a repair has been made

mental.eng_def: relating to the mind, or involving the process of thinking
mental.chi_def: 精神的；思想上的；心理的
mental.eg: The family has a history of mental disorder.

mentality.eng_def: a person's particular way of thinking about things
mentality.eg: I can't understand the mentality of people who hurt animals.

mention.eng_def: to speak about something quickly, giving little detail or using few words
mention.eg: I'll mention your ideas to Jacinta.

mention.eng_def: to refer to something or someone
mention.eg: I promised never to mention the incident again.

mention.eng_def: a short remark or written statement
mention.eg: The story didn't even get a mention in the newspaper.

mention.eng_def: an occasion when something or someone is mentioned
mention.eg: Even the mention of her name makes him blush.

mention.eng_def: an occasion when a person is publicly praised for having done something, such as their job, extremely well
mention.eg: At the awards ceremony, Chrissie Scott got/received a special mention for her reporting on the conflict.

menu.eng_def: a list of the food that you can eat in a restaurant
menu.eg: The waiter brought the menu and the wine list.

menu.eng_def: a list of choices that can be made to appear on a computer screen
menu.chi_def: （電腦螢幕上顯示的）功能表，選單
menu.eg: Select the "Edit" menu and then choose "Copy".

merchandise.eng_def: goods that are bought and sold
merchandise.eg: Shoppers complained about poor quality merchandise and high prices.

merchandise.eng_def: to encourage the sale of goods by advertising them or by making certain that they are noticed
merchandise.eg: She had to merchandise the new product line.

merchant.eng_def: a person whose job is to buy and sell products in large amounts, especially by trading with other countries
someone who is involved in or enjoys something that is unpleasant or annoying to others
merchant.chi_def: 對（令人討厭之事）入迷的人，好…的人
merchant.eg: a gossip merchant (= someone who enjoys talking about people's private lives)

mercy.eng_def: kindness that makes you forgive someone, usually someone that you have authority over
mercy.eg: She appealed to the judge to have mercy on her husband.

mercy.eng_def: to be in a situation where someone or something has complete power over you
mercy.chi_def: 任由…的擺布，完全受…的支配
mercy.eg: Poor people are increasingly at the mercy of money-lenders.

mercy.eng_def: an event or situation that you are grateful for because it stops something unpleasant
mercy.eg: After months of suffering, his death was a mercy.

mere.eng_def: used to emphasize that something is not large or important
mere.chi_def: （用於強調不大，不重要或效果不大）只不過的，僅僅的
mere.eg: The plane crashed mere minutes after take-off.

mere.eng_def: used to emphasize how strongly someone feels about something or how extreme a situation is
mere.chi_def: （用於強調感受強烈或極為重要）僅僅地
mere.eg: The mere thought of it (= just thinking about it) makes me feel sick.

merge.eng_def: to combine or join together, or to cause things to do this
merge.eg: They decided to merge the two companies into one.

merge.eng_def: to join a line of moving traffic without causing other vehicles to slow down

merit.eng_def: the quality of being good and deserving praise
merit.eg: an entertaining film with little artistic merit

merit.eng_def: the advantages something has compared to something else
merit.eg: We discussed the merits of herbal tea.

merit.eng_def: according to the qualities you have or have shown, without considering any other information or comparing you to someone else
merit.eg: The committee will consider/judge each applicant on his or her own merits.

merit.eng_def: If something merits a particular treatment, it deserves or is considered important enough to be treated in that way.

mermaid.eng_def: an imaginary creature described in stories, with the upper body of a woman and the tail of a fish

merry.chi_def: 愉快的，快樂的，興高采烈的

merry.eng_def: UK polite word for slightly drunk
merry.eg: You got a bit merry last night, didn't you Cath?

mess.eng_def: Something or someone that is a mess, or is in a mess, looks dirty or untidy.
mess.eg: He makes a terrible mess when he's cooking.
Fido left another mess on the carpet.

mess.eng_def: a situation that is full of problems
mess.eg: She said that her life was a mess.

mess.eng_def: a person whose life is full of problems they cannot deal with
mess.eg: After the divorce he was a real mess and started drinking too much.

mess.eng_def: to do something badly or spoil something
mess.eg: I made a real mess of my final exams.

mess.eng_def: a room or building in which members of the armed forces have their meals or spend their free time
mess.eg: The captain was having breakfast in the mess hall.

mess.eng_def: a large public room where people have their meals

mess.eg: Don't you dare mess my hair!
The neighbour's dog has messed on our lawn again!

message.eng_def: a short piece of information that you give to a person when you cannot speak to them directly
message.eg: If I'm not there when you call, leave a message.

message.eng_def: the most important idea in a book, film, or play, or an idea that you want to tell people about
message.chi_def: （書、電影或戲劇的）要旨，寓意，中心思想
message.eg: The movie's message is that rich and poor are alike.

message.eng_def: to understand what someone is trying to tell you, even if that person is not expressing himself or herself directly
message.eg: I never answer his calls, so you'd think he'd get the message.
We need to get the message across that too much sun is dangerous.

message.eng_def: to send someone a short message using a mobile phone or computer
message.eg: I messaged him yesterday but haven't had a reply.

messenger.eng_def: someone who takes a message or documents from one person to another
messenger.eg: The documents were delivered by special messenger.

messy.eng_def: producing or causing dirt and untidiness
messy.chi_def: 會把東西弄髒的，導致周圍變得雜亂的
messy.eg: Eating spaghetti can be a messy business.

messy.eng_def: used to describe a situation that is confused and unpleasant
messy.eg: A war will be a long and messy business.

metal.eng_def: a chemical element, such as iron or gold, or a mixture of such elements, such as steel, that is generally hard and strong, and through which electricity and heat can travel
metal.eg: Metal, paper, and glass can be recycled.

metaphor.eng_def: an expression, often found in literature, that describes a person or object by referring to something that is considered to have similar characteristics to that person or object
metaphor.eg: "The mind is an ocean" and "the city is a jungle" are both metaphors.

meter.eng_def: a device that measures the amount of something that is used
meter.eg: The electricity meter is in the basement.

meter.eng_def: the device in a taxi that measures the distance or the amount of time spent travelling and shows how much you have to pay
meter.eg: The cab driver left the meter running while I helped Mum to her front door.

meter.eng_def: to use meters to measure how much gas, electricity, or water is used
meter.eg: Britain's water companies are planning to meter water consumption.

method.eng_def: a particular way of doing something
method.eg: Travelling by train is still one of the safest methods of transport.

metro.eng_def: an underground electric railway system in some cities

metro.eg: Our company has developed commercial properties across the four metros in India.

metro.eng_def: relating to a large city and the area surrounding it
metro.eg: This guidebook includes a map of the Phoenix metro area.

metropolitan.eg: the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York

microphone.eng_def: a piece of equipment that you speak into to make your voice louder, or to record your voice or other sounds
microphone.eg: The interviewer asked her to speak into/use the microphone.

microscope.eng_def: a device that uses lenses to make very small objects look larger, so that they can be scientifically examined and studied
microscope.eg: They looked at the blood samples under the microscope.

microwave.eng_def: an electric oven that uses waves of energy to cook or heat food quickly
microwave.eg: Put the fish in the microwave and it'll only take five minutes.

microwave.eng_def: a very short electromagnetic wave used for cooking food or for sending information by radio or radar
to cook something in a microwave
microwave.eg: Shall I microwave something for dinner?

middle.eng_def: the central point, position, or part
middle.eg: This is my class photo - I'm the one in the middle.
Those trousers look a bit tight around your middle.

middle.chi_def: 中部的，中間的；中央的；正中的
middle.eg: In the sequence a, b, c, d, e, the middle letter is c.

middle.eng_def: neither high nor low in importance, amount, or size
A middle child has the same number of older brothers and sisters as younger brothers and sisters.
middle.chi_def: （在兄弟姐妹當中）排行居中的
middle.eg: She's the middle child of three.

middle.eng_def: used to refer to a form of a particular language that existed between its earliest known stage and its present form
middle.chi_def: （語言）中古的，介於古代與現代之間的

midst.eng_def: the middle of a group of people or things
midst.eg: She caught sight of Johnny in their midst (= among them), laughing and talking.

midst.eng_def: in the middle of an event, situation, or activity
midst.eg: I'm sorry but I'm too busy - I'm in the midst of writing a report.

might.eng_def: past simple of the verb may, used especially when reporting what someone has said, thought, asked, etc.
might.eg: I brought him some sandwiches because I thought he might be hungry.

might.eng_def: used to express the possibility that something will happen or be done, or that something is true although not very likely
might.eg: I might come and visit you next year, if I can save enough money.

might.eng_def: used as a more polite form of may when asking for permission
might.chi_def: （用於請求許可，語氣較 may 更婉轉）可以，能

might.eng_def: used to make a suggestion or suggest a possibility in a polite way
might.eg: You might try a little more basil in the sauce next time.

might.eng_def: used to suggest, especially angrily, what someone should do to be pleasant, correct, polite, etc.
might.eg: You might at least try to look like you're enjoying yourself!

might.eng_def: used to introduce a statement that is very different from the statement you really want to make, in order to compare the two
might.chi_def: （用於引出與真正想說的話完全不同的話，以將兩者對比）也許

Pizarro defeated the might of the Inca Empire with only a few hundred men.

mighty.eg: In the next game they will face the mighty Patriots.
They offered to raise salaries by 15 percent - that's a mighty generous deal.

migrant.eng_def: a person that travels to a different country or place, often in order to find work
migrant.eg: The cities are full of migrants looking for work.

migrant.eng_def: an animal that moves from one place to another at different times of the year
migrant.eg: These birds are winter migrants from Scandinavia.

migrant.eng_def: travelling to a different country or place, often in order to find work
moving from one place to another at different times of year

migrate.eng_def: When an animal migrates, it travels to a different place, usually when the season changes.
migrate.eg: These animals migrate annually in search of food.

migrate.eng_def: If people migrate, they travel in large numbers to a new place to live temporarily.
migrate.chi_def: （指人）大批外出；（暫時）移居，遷移
migrate.eg: Mexican farm workers migrate into the US each year to find work at harvest time.

migrate.eng_def: to move from one place to another
migrate.eg: Trade has migrated from local shops to the larger chain stores.

migrate.eng_def: to begin using a new computer system, or to move information from one type of system to another
migrate.chi_def: 轉移（使用新的作業系統，或將資料從一種作業系統移至另一種作業系統）
migrate.eg: Migrating to Windows XP shouldn't cause you any problems.

mike.chi_def: 擴音器，麥克風，話筒（microphone的非正式说法）

mild.eg: She can't accept even mild criticism of her work.

mild.eng_def: Mild weather is not very cold or not as cold as usual.
mild.eg: We've had a mild winter this year.

mild.eng_def: used to describe food or a food flavour that is not very strong
mild.chi_def: （食物或其味道）不濃烈的，淡的
mild.eg: He doesn't like a hot curry - he prefers a mild one.
a shy, mild sort of guy

mild.eng_def: a dark beer that does not have a very strong or bitter taste

mile.eng_def: a unit of distance equal to 1,760 yards or 1.6 kilometres
mile.chi_def: 英里（長度單位，相當於1760碼或1.6公里）

mile.eg: From the top, we could see for miles in every direction.

mileage.eng_def: the distance that a vehicle has travelled or the distance that it can travel using a particular amount of fuel
mileage.chi_def: 英里數；英里里程；某固定油量的行車里程
mileage.eg: "What's the mileage on your car?" "Oh, about 40,000."

mileage.eng_def: the amount of money that you are paid or that you must pay for each mile you travel
mileage.chi_def: 按英里計算的交通補貼；按英里計算的收費
mileage.eg: The car costs £70 a day to rent, but you get unlimited mileage (= no charge for the miles travelled).

mileage.eng_def: the advantage that you can get from a situation
mileage.eg: There's no mileage in complaining to the director - she'll just ignore you.

milestone.eng_def: a stone or post at the side of the road that shows the distance to various places, especially to the nearest large town
an important event in the development or history of something or in someone's life
milestone.chi_def: 里程碑；重大事件；轉捩點
milestone.eg: He felt that moving out of his parents' home was a real milestone in his life.

militant.eng_def: active, determined, and often willing to use force
militant.chi_def: 激進的；行動積極的；好戰的，好鬥的

military.eng_def: relating to or belonging to the armed forces

military.eg: The military has opposed any cuts in defence spending.

milk.eng_def: the white liquid produced by cows, goats, and sheep and used by humans as a drink or for making butter, cheese, etc.
the white liquid produced by women and other female mammals as food for their young
milk.chi_def: （女性及雌性哺乳動物的）奶，乳汁
milk.eg: Breast/Mother's milk is the best nourishment for a baby.

milk.eng_def: the white liquid produced by some plants and trees
to get milk from an animal
milk.eg: Milking a cow by hand is a skilled process.

milk.eng_def: to get as much money or information out of someone or something as possible, often in an unfair or dishonest way
milk.eg: The newspapers milked the story dry.

mill.eng_def: a building where grain is crushed into flour
a small machine for crushing things into powder
a factory where a particular substance is produced
to crush grain into flour or another substance into powder
mill.eg: The grain is still milled locally.

mill.eng_def: to cut or shape metal, especially coins, using a special machine

miller.eng_def: a person, especially in the past, who owned or was in charge of a mill
miller.chi_def: （尤指舊時的）磨坊主；麵粉廠主

million.eg: The city has a population of almost a/one million.
I must have told you a million times to close the windows when you leave the house.

million.chi_def: 一百萬與十億間的數字
million.eg: In wealthy areas, homes cost from €750,000 into the millions.

millionaire.eng_def: a person who has money, property, etc. that is worth at least 1,000,000 dollars, pounds, euros, etc.
millionaire.eg: You want me to buy you a new car - do you think I'm a millionaire or something?

mimic.eng_def: to copy the way in which a particular person usually speaks and moves, usually in order to make people laugh
mimic.eg: She was mimicking the various people in our office.

mimic.eng_def: a person who can copy the sounds or movements of other people

mind.eng_def: the part of a person that makes it possible for him or her to think, feel emotions, and understand things
mind.eg: Her mind was full of what had happened the night before, and she just wasn't concentrating.
She was one of the most brilliant minds of the last century.

mind.eng_def: If a problem is all in the mind, it does not exist and is only imagined.
mind.chi_def: 全是心理作用的；只是憑空想像的
mind.eg: His doctor tried to convince him that he wasn't really ill and that it was all in his mind.

mind.eng_def: to remember a piece of information when you are making a decision or thinking about a matter
mind.eg: Bearing in mind how young she is, I thought she did really well.

mind.eng_def: to think repeatedly about an event that has happened
mind.eg: She kept going over the accident again and again in her mind, wishing that she could somehow have prevented it.

mind.eng_def: (used in questions and negatives) to be annoyed or worried by something
mind.chi_def: （用於疑問句和否定句）介意，反對
mind.eg: Do you think he'd mind if I borrowed his book?

mind.eng_def: said to someone when you feel annoyed with that person for what they have just done or said
mind.chi_def: （對某人的言行表示惱火）你怎麼回事？你別這樣好不好？
mind.eg: Do you mind? That's my seat you're sitting on!

mind.eng_def: to be careful of, or give attention to something
mind.eg: Mind that box - the bottom isn't very strong.

mind.eng_def: used to tell someone to move or be careful, or to warn someone of danger
mind.eg: Mind out! We're coming through with the stretcher.

mind.eng_def: said when you say goodbye to someone, meaning "take care"
to take care of someone or something
mind.eg: She asked me if I'd mind the children for an hour while she went shopping.

mind.eng_def: to listen to and obey someone

mine.eng_def: the one(s) belonging to or connected with me
mine.chi_def: 我的（所有物）；屬於我的（東西）；與我有關的（人）

mine.eng_def: a hole or system of holes in the ground where substances such as coal, metal, and salt are removed
a type of bomb put below the earth or in the sea that explodes when vehicles, ships, or people go over it
mine.eg: He was killed when his tank ran over a mine.

mine.eng_def: to dig coal or another substance out of the ground
to place or hide mines in an area of land or sea
used in the past instead of "my" before nouns that begin with a vowel or h
mine.chi_def: （舊時用在以母音或h開頭的名詞前，代替my使用）

miner.eng_def: a person who works in a mine

mineral.eng_def: a valuable or useful chemical substance that is formed naturally in the ground
a chemical that your body needs to stay healthy
mineral.eg: A healthy diet should supply all necessary vitamins and minerals.

mineral.eng_def: cold, sweet fizzy drinks (= ones with bubbles) without alcohol
mineral.chi_def: 無酒精而味甜的泡騰冷飲；汽水

mineral.eng_def: being or consisting of a mineral or minerals
mineral.chi_def: 礦物的；含礦物的，有礦物質的
mineral.eg: a mineral deposit (= substance or layer that is left)

mingle.eng_def: to mix or combine, or be mixed or combined
mingle.eg: The excitement of starting a new job is always mingled with a certain apprehension.

mingle.eng_def: to move around and talk to other people at a social event
mingle.eg: You've been talking to Roger all evening - you really ought to be mingling with the other guests.

miniature.eng_def: used to describe something that is a very small copy of an object
miniature.eg: I bought some miniature furniture for my niece's doll's house.

miniature.eng_def: a very small painting, usually of a person
a very small bottle of alcoholic drink

miniature.eg: The model railway has all the buildings, bridges, and trees in miniature.

minimal.eg: There were no injuries and damage to the building was minimal.

minimize.eng_def: to reduce something to the least possible level or amount
minimize.chi_def: 使降到最低限度；使減到最少
minimize.eg: We must minimize the risk of infection.

minimize.eng_def: to make something seem less important or smaller than it really is
minimize.eg: She accused politicians of minimizing the suffering of thousands of people.

minimize.eng_def: to make something small on a computer screen
minimize.chi_def: 使（電腦螢幕上的）…最小化
minimize.eg: Minimize the window by clicking in the corner.

minimum.eng_def: the smallest amount or number allowed or possible
minimum.chi_def: 最小值；最少量；最低限度
minimum.eg: Wage increases are being kept to a minimum because of the recession.

minimum.eng_def: used to describe something that is the smallest or least allowed or possible
minimum.chi_def: 最低的，最小的，最低限度的
minimum.eg: This certificate is the minimum qualification required to teach English in most language schools.
She thinks that you should do three exercise classes a week minimum.

minister.eng_def: a member of the government in Britain and many other countries who is in charge of a particular department or has an important position in it
a religious leader in certain Christian churches
minister.eg: a minister at the local Baptist church

minister.eng_def: a person below the rank of ambassador whose job is to represent his or her country in a foreign country

ministry.eng_def: in Britain and some other countries, a department of the government led by a minister

ministry.eg: He practised a preaching and teaching ministry there for over 40 years.

ministry.eng_def: the job of being a priest
ministry.eg: In 1985 he decided to go into/leave the ministry.

minor.eng_def: having little importance, influence, or effect, especially when compared with other things of the same type
minor.chi_def: 較不重要的；次要的；輕微的

minor.eng_def: belonging or relating to a musical scale that is generally thought to have a sad sound
minor.eg: The piece is written in a minor key.

minor.eng_def: someone who is too young to have the legal responsibilities of an adult
minor.eg: He was accused of having sex with a minor.

minor.eng_def: to study something as your second most important subject in college
minor.eg: I minored in Spanish in college.

minority.eg: It's only a tiny minority of people who are causing the problem.

minority.eng_def: any small group in society that is different from the rest because of their race, religion, or political beliefs, or a person who belongs to such a group
minority.chi_def: 少數民族；少數派；少數民族人士；少數派人士

mint.eng_def: a herb whose leaves have a strong, fresh smell and taste and are used for giving flavour to food
a sweet with a mint flavour
a place where the new coins of a country are made
an extremely large amount of money
mint.eg: If his books sell worldwide, he'll make a mint.

mint.eng_def: Mint stamps and coins, etc. have not been used.
mint.eg: A collector would pay $500 for a mint copy.
I bought a two-year-old car, in mint condition, with less than 20,000 miles.

mint.eng_def: to produce a coin for the government
to produce something new, especially to invent a new phrase or word

minus.eg: We're minus a chair for Elsa - could you get one from the other room?

minus.eng_def: a disadvantage or a bad feature
minus.eg: Having to travel such a long way to work is a definite minus.

minus.eng_def: the (-) sign, written between two numbers to show that the second number should be taken away from the first, or in front of one number to show that it has a value of less than 0
A minus number or amount is less than zero.
used to show that temperatures are less than zero
minus.eg: Temperatures could fall to minus eight tonight.

minus.eng_def: used after a mark given to written work to mean that it is of a slightly lower standard than that mark
minus.eg: I got A minus for my English homework.

minus.eng_def: used to describe a disadvantage or bad point
minus.eg: One of the minus points of working at home is not having social contact with colleagues.

minute.eng_def: one of the 60 parts that an hour is divided into, consisting of 60 seconds
used in spoken English to mean a very short time
minute.eg: Hang on/Wait a minute - I just have to get my bag.

minute.eng_def: the written record of what was said at a meeting
minute.eg: Could you take/do (= write) the minutes, Daniel?

minute.eng_def: an official message from one person to another in an organization
minute.eg: I've just received a minute from Clark authorizing the purchase of six more computers.

minute.eng_def: any of the 60 parts that the degrees of any angle are divided into
to make a written record of what is said at a meeting
minute.chi_def: 把…寫進議事錄，把…寫進會議紀錄
minute.eg: The chairman is minuted as having said that profits had fallen to an all-time low.

miracle.eng_def: an unusual and mysterious event that is thought to have been caused by a god because it does not follow the usual laws of nature
miracle.eg: Jesus Christ was said to have performed miracles like turning water into wine.

miracle.eng_def: a very lucky event that is surprising and unexpected
miracle.eg: Looking at the state of his car, it's a miracle (that) he wasn't killed!

miracle.eng_def: an excellent achievement in a particular area of activity
miracle.eg: I considered my recovery to be a miracle of modern medicine.

miraculous.eng_def: very effective or surprising, or difficult to believe
miraculous.chi_def: 奇跡般的；令人驚奇的；不可思議的
miraculous.eg: The diet promised miraculous weight loss.

mirror.eng_def: a piece of glass with a shiny, metal-covered back that reflects light, producing an image of whatever is in front of it
to represent or show something honestly
mirror.chi_def: 是…的寫照；是…的真實反映
mirror.eg: The movie is a mirror of daily life in wartime Britain.
Our newspaper aims to mirror the opinions of ordinary people.

mirror.eng_def: to be very similar to something
mirror.eg: Her on-screen romances seem to mirror her experiences in her private life.

mischief.eng_def: behaviour, especially a child's, that is slightly bad but is not intended to cause serious harm or damage
mischief.chi_def: （尤指兒童的）惡作劇，淘氣，搗蛋
mischief.eg: She's a lively little girl, full of mischief.

mischievous.eng_def: behaving in a way, or describing behaviour, that is slightly bad but is not intended to cause serious harm or damage
mischievous.chi_def: （人、行為等）愛惡作劇的，好搗亂的，頑皮的，淘氣的
mischievous.eg: She has a mischievous sense of humour.

mischievous.eng_def: used to describe behaviour or words that are intended to cause harm or trouble
mischievous.chi_def: （行為）有害的；（話語）惡意中傷的
mischievous.eg: I think these rumours are mischievous.

miser.eng_def: someone who has a strong wish to have money and hates to spend it
miser.chi_def: 守財奴，財迷；吝嗇鬼，小氣鬼

miserable.eg: She's miserable living on her own.

miserable.chi_def: 令人難受的，令人痛苦的

miserable.eng_def: used to emphasize the low quality of value of something
miserable.eg: The book was a miserable failure.

misery.eg: We have witnessed the most appalling scenes of human misery.

misery.eng_def: someone who is often very unhappy and is always complaining about things
misery.chi_def: 常常不高興的人，老發牢騷的人
misery.eg: Oh come on, don't be such a misery!

misfortune.eng_def: bad luck, or an unlucky event
misfortune.chi_def: 不幸；厄運；不幸事故；災難
misfortune.eg: That was the worst film I've ever had the misfortune to see.

mislead.eng_def: to cause someone to believe something that is not true
mislead.chi_def: 誤導；使…產生錯誤的想法；把…引入歧途
mislead.eg: He has admitted misleading the police about his movements on the night of the murder.

miss.eng_def: to fail to do or experience something, often something planned or expected, or to avoid doing or experiencing something
miss.chi_def: 未做到；未體驗；避開；倖免於
miss.eg: I missed the start of the class because my bus was late.

miss.eng_def: to arrive too late to get on a bus, train, or aircraft
miss.eg: You'll miss your flight if you don't hurry up.
Students who miss a lot of school can find it hard to catch up.

miss.eng_def: to not see or hear something or someone
miss.eg: I missed the beginning of the show.

miss.eng_def: to not notice someone or something
miss.eg: You don't miss much, do you? Nobody else noticed that mistake.

miss.eng_def: to feel sad that a person or thing is not present
miss.eg: I really missed her when she went away.

miss.eng_def: to fail to hit something, or to avoid hitting something
miss.eg: The bullet missed his heart by a couple of centimetres.

miss.eng_def: to notice that something is lost or absent
miss.chi_def: 發覺遺失；發覺…不在身邊
miss.eg: He didn't miss his wallet until the waiter brought the bill.

miss.eng_def: an occasion when something or someone fails to hit something or avoids hitting something
miss.eg: Well done! You scored eight hits and only two misses.

miss.eng_def: to avoid or not do something
miss.chi_def: 避開；對…不予理會；決定不做
miss.eg: We usually go to France in the summer, but we've decided to give it a miss this year.

miss.eng_def: a girl or young woman, especially one who behaves rudely or shows no respect
miss.eg: You're a cheeky little miss! Apologize at once.

miss.eng_def: a title used before the family name or full name of a single woman who has no other title
miss.chi_def: （用在女孩或未婚女子名字前作為稱呼）小姐
miss.eg: Dr White will see you now, Miss Carter.

miss.eng_def: used as a form of address for a girl or young woman
miss.chi_def: （作為對看來沒有結婚的女孩或青年女子的稱呼）小姐
miss.eg: Excuse me, Miss, you dropped this.

miss.eng_def: sometimes used by children to address or refer to teachers who are women
miss.chi_def: （孩子有時對女教師的稱呼）老師
miss.eg: Can I go to the toilet, Miss?

miss.eng_def: a title given to a woman who wins a beauty contest, combined with the name of the place that she represents

missile.eng_def: a flying weapon that has its own engine so that it can travel a long distance before exploding at the place that it has been aimed at
any object that is thrown with the intention of causing injury or damage
missile.eg: Stones, bottles, and other missiles were thrown at the police.

missing.eng_def: Someone who is missing has disappeared.
missing.eg: Her father has been missing since September 1992.

missing.eng_def: Something that is missing cannot be found because it is not where it should be.
missing.eg: The burglars have been arrested but the jewellery is still missing.

missing.eng_def: Missing soldiers or military vehicles have not returned from fighting in a war but are not known completely certainly to be dead or destroyed.
missing.chi_def: （士兵及軍用車輛在戰爭中）失蹤的，下落不明的
missing.eg: He was listed as missing in action.

mission.eng_def: an important job, especially a military one, that someone is sent somewhere to do
mission.eg: Your mission is to isolate the enemy by destroying all the bridges across the river.

mission.eng_def: any work that someone believes it is their duty to do
mission.eg: My mission in life is to educate the rich about the suffering of the poor.

mission.eng_def: something that you say when you have finished doing something that you were told to do
mission.eg: Mission accomplished. I've got everything you asked for on the list.

mission.eng_def: a group of people whose job is to increase what is known about their country, organization, or religion in another country or area, or the place where such people are based
mission.chi_def: 外交使團，代表團，佈道團；外交使團（或代表團）駐所，佈道所
mission.eg: More funds are needed to establish trade missions in eastern Europe.

missionary.eng_def: a person who has been sent to a foreign country to teach their religion to the people who live there
missionary.eg: He did missionary work for the Presbyterian Church in Alaska.

mist.eng_def: thin fog produced by very small drops of water collecting in the air just above an area of ground or water
mist.eg: The mountain villages seem to be permanently shrouded in mist.

mist.eng_def: a thin layer of liquid on the surface of something that makes it difficult to see
mist.eg: There's always a mist on the bathroom mirror/windows when I've had a shower.

mistake.eng_def: an action, decision, or judgment that produces an unwanted or unintentional result
mistake.eg: I'm not blaming you - we all make mistakes.
I've paid this bill twice by mistake.

mistake.eng_def: to be wrong about or to fail to recognize something or someone
mistake.eg: You can't mistake their house - it has a bright yellow front door.

mister.eng_def: the complete form of the title  Mr
an informal and sometimes rude form of address for a man whose name you do not know
mister.chi_def: （對不知姓名的男子的非正式稱呼，常顯得不禮貌）先生
mister.eg: Listen to me, mister, I don't ever wanna see you in this bar again.

mistress.eng_def: a woman who has control over or responsibility for someone or something
mistress.chi_def: 女主人；女能人；起主宰作用的女子
mistress.eg: I'll inform the mistress (of the house) of your arrival, madam.
She got a good report from her German mistress.

mistress.eng_def: a female owner of a dog
a woman who is having a sexual relationship with a married man
mistress.eg: Edward VII and his mistress, Lillie Langtry

misunderstand.eng_def: to think you have understood someone or something when you have not
misunderstand.eg: If you think that these transport problems can be solved by building more roads, you completely misunderstand the nature of the problem.

misunderstand.eng_def: If someone is misunderstood, other people do not understand that they have good qualities.
misunderstand.eg: In her teens she felt frustrated and misunderstood.

mix.eng_def: to (cause different substances to) combine, so that the result cannot easily be separated into its parts
mix.eg: Oil and water don't mix. Even if you shake them together they separate into two layers.

mix.eng_def: to have or do two or more things, such as activities or qualities, at the same time
mix.chi_def: 把…結合起來，使同時進行
mix.eg: Some people are happy to mix business with/and pleasure, but I'm not one of them.

mix.eng_def: to be with or communicate well with other people
mix.eg: Do you mix with a wide variety of people in your job?

mix.eng_def: to control the amounts of various sounds that are combined on a recording

mix.eg: There was an odd mix of people at Patrick's party.

mix.eng_def: something that is sold in the form of a powder to which a liquid, such as water, can be added later
a version of a recorded piece of music
mix.eg: A new mix of their hit single is due to be released early next month.

mixture.eng_def: a substance made from a combination of different substances, or any combination of different things
mixture.eg: The mixture of flour, water, and yeast is then left in a warm place for four hours.

mixture.eng_def: a type of medicine that has to be shaken before being used

moan.eng_def: to make a long, low sound of pain, suffering, or another strong emotion
moan.eg: He moaned with pain before losing consciousness.

moan.eng_def: to make a complaint in an unhappy voice, usually about something that does not seem important to other people
moan.eg: Thelma's always moaning (about something), and forgets how lucky she actually is.

moan.eng_def: a long, low sound of pain, suffering, or another strong emotion
moan.eg: We could hear the moans of someone trapped under the rubble.

moan.eng_def: the act of complaining about something, or a complaint
moan.eg: Apart from a slight moan about the waiter, he seemed to enjoy the meal.

mob.eng_def: a large, angry crowd, especially one that could easily become violent
mob.eg: The angry mob outside the jail was/were ready to riot.

mob.eng_def: a group of people who are friends or who are similar in some way
mob.eg: The usual mob was/were hanging out at the bar.

mob.eng_def: to come together around someone in a crowd to express admiration, interest, or anger
mob.eg: They were mobbed by fans when they arrived at the theatre.

mob.eng_def: When birds or small animals mob a bigger or more frightening bird or animal that is hunting them, they attack it together and force it to go away.
mob.chi_def: （鳥群或一群小動物）成群襲擊，圍攻（猛禽或猛獸）

mobile.eg: You've broken your ankle but you'll be fully mobile within a couple of months.

mobile.eng_def: able to be moved from one place to another
used to describe a service available on a mobile phone, small computer, etc.
mobile.chi_def: （服務）可以在行動電話（或小型電腦）上提供的
行動電話，手機，手提電話（同 mobile phone）
行動電話號碼（同 mobile number）

mobile.eng_def: a decoration or work of art that has many parts that move freely in the air, for example hanging from threads
mobile.chi_def: 風鈴；（可隨風擺動的）懸掛飾物

mobilize.eng_def: to organize or prepare something, such as a group of people, for a purpose
mobilize.eg: Representatives for all the main candidates are trying to mobilize voter support.

mobilize.eng_def: to prepare to fight, especially in a war
mobilize.eg: The government has mobilized several of the army's top combat units.

mock.eng_def: to laugh at someone, often by copying them in a funny but unkind way
mock.chi_def: 嘲笑，嘲弄；（常指為取笑而）模仿
mock.eg: They were mocking him because he kept falling off his bike.

mock.eng_def: to make something appear stupid or not effective
mock.eg: The wind mocked their attempts to reach the shore by pushing the boat further and further out to sea.

mock.eng_def: not real but appearing or pretending to be exactly like something
an exam taken at school for practice before a real exam
mock.eg: You will have your mocks during the first two weeks of March.

mode.eng_def: a way of operating, living, or behaving
mode.eg: Each department in the company has its own mode of operation.

mode.eng_def: the number or value that appears most often in a particular set
mode.chi_def: 眾數（指某一組數字資料中出現次數最多的值）

mode.eng_def: (especially of clothes) to be fashionable at a particular time
mode.eg: Miniskirts were very much the mode in the 60s.

model.eng_def: something that a copy can be based on because it is an extremely good example of its type
model.eg: The educational system was a model for those of many other countries.

model.eng_def: a person who wears clothes so that they can be photographed or shown to possible buyers, or a person who is employed to be photographed or painted
a particular type of machine, especially a car, that is slightly different from machines of the same type
model.chi_def: （汽車等的）型號；特定型號的汽車

model.eng_def: something that represents another thing, either as a physical object that is usually smaller than the real object, or as a simple description that can be used in calculations
to wear fashionable clothes, jewellery, etc. in order to advertise them
model.eg: Tatjana is modelling a Versace design.

model.eng_def: to make a model of something
model.eg: to model animals out of clay

moderate.eng_def: neither small nor large in size, amount, degree, or strength
moderate.chi_def: 中等的；不過分的，適度的
moderate.eg: The cabin is of moderate size - just right for a small family.

moderate.eng_def: Moderate opinions, especially political ones, are not extreme and are therefore acceptable to a large number of people.
moderate.chi_def: （尤指政見）溫和的，不激烈的，不偏激的
moderate.eg: The party includes both extremely conservative and moderate members.

moderate.eng_def: a person whose opinions, especially their political ones, are not extreme and are therefore acceptable to a large number of people
moderate.eg: He is well-known as a moderate in the party.

moderate.eng_def: to (cause to) become less in size, strength, or force; to reduce something
moderate.chi_def: （使）緩和；（使）適中；減輕，減弱；節制
moderate.eg: The president may have to moderate his stance on tax cuts.

moderate.eng_def: to make certain that all the people marking an examination use the same standards
moderate.chi_def: 審核評分（以確保不同閱卷人的評分標準是一致的）
moderate.eg: The marked scripts are sent away to be moderated.

modern.eng_def: designed and made using the most recent ideas and methods
of the present or recent times, especially the period of history since around 1500
modern.eg: What do you think is the role of religion in the modern world?

modernize.eg: Much of the house has been modernized.

modest.eng_def: not large in size or amount, or not expensive
modest.eg: They live in a fairly modest house, considering their wealth.

modest.eng_def: not usually talking about or making obvious your own abilities and achievements
modest.eg: He's very modest about his achievements.

modest.eng_def: used to describe something, such as a woman's clothes or behaviour, that is intended to avoid attracting sexual interest
modest.chi_def: （女子的衣著、舉止等）端莊的，正派的，樸素的

modesty.eng_def: the quality of not talking about or not trying to make people notice your abilities and achievements
modesty.eg: She does a lot of work for charities, but her modesty forbids her from talking about it.

modesty.eng_def: said when you want to say something good about yourself, but do not want to seem to think you are too important
modesty.chi_def: （用於謙遜地談論自己的優點時）並不是要自誇，毫不誇張地說
modesty.eg: In all modesty, we'd probably have lost the game if I hadn't been playing.

modesty.eng_def: the quality, in women, of dressing or behaving in a way that is intended to avoid attracting sexual interest
modesty.chi_def: （女子的衣著、舉止等）端莊，正派，樸素

modify.eng_def: to change something such as a plan, opinion, law, or way of behaviour slightly, usually to improve it or make it more acceptable
modify.eg: Instead of simply punishing them, the system encourages offenders to modify their behaviour.

modify.eng_def: If a word or phrase modifies another word or phrase used with it, it limits or adds to its meaning.
modify.eg: In the sentence "She ran quickly" the adverb "quickly" modifies the verb "ran".

moist.eng_def: slightly wet, especially in a good way
moist.eg: Keep the soil in the pot moist, but not too wet.

moisture.eng_def: a liquid such as water in the form of very small drops, either in the air, in a substance, or on a surface
moisture.eg: These plants need a rich soil that retains moisture.

molecule.eng_def: the simplest unit of a chemical substance, usually a group of two or more atoms

mom.eg: I miss my mom and dad a lot.

moment.eng_def: a very short period of time

moment.eg: When would be the best moment to tell the family?
Sorry, she's not here at the moment.

moment.eng_def: If you do something for the moment, you are doing it now, but might do something different in the future.
moment.eg: Let's keep doing what we agreed for the moment.
I can give no information at this precise moment in time.

momentum.eng_def: the force that keeps an object moving or keeps an event developing after it has started
momentum.chi_def: 動量，衝量；衝力；推動力；動力
momentum.eg: Once you push it, it keeps going under its own momentum.

monarch.chi_def: 君主；國王，皇帝；女王，女皇

money.eng_def: coins or notes (= special pieces of paper) that are used to buy things, or an amount of these that a person has
money.eg: "How much money do you have on you?" "€100 in notes and a few coins."

money.eng_def: If you say that there is money in something, you mean that the activity will produce a profit.
money.eg: There's money in sport these days.

monitor.eng_def: a person who has the job of watching or noticing particular things
monitor.eg: United Nations monitors were not allowed to enter the area.

monitor.eng_def: a machine that regularly tests something
a computer screen or a device with a screen on which words or pictures can be shown
a child in school who has special jobs to do
monitor.chi_def: （學校的）班長，級長，教務助理生

monitor.eng_def: to watch and check a situation carefully for a period of time in order to discover something about it
monitor.chi_def: 監控；監測；監視，密切注視
monitor.eg: The new findings suggest that women ought to monitor their cholesterol levels.

monk.eng_def: a member of a group of religious men who do not marry and usually live together in a monastery

monkey.eng_def: an animal that lives in hot countries, has a long tail, and climbs trees. Monkeys are primates (= the group of animals that are most like humans) .

monkey.eg: They ate all the cakes, the monkeys.

monopoly.eng_def: (an organization or group that has) complete control of something, especially an area of business, so that others have no share
monopoly.eg: The government is determined to protect its tobacco monopoly.

monotonous.chi_def: 單調乏味的；毫無變化的

monotony.eng_def: a situation in which something stays the same and is therefore boring
monotony.eg: The monotony of motorway driving can cause accidents.

monster.eng_def: any imaginary frightening creature, especially one that is large and strange

monster.chi_def: 喪失人性的人；殘忍的人，惡人
monster.eg: You'd have to be a monster to hit a child like that.

monster.eng_def: something that is very big, or too big
monster.eg: You should have seen the onions he grew for the competition - they were monsters!

monster.eng_def: to criticize someone severely or to treat someone very badly
monster.eg: Andy Smith has been monstered by the media.

monstrous.chi_def: 醜惡的；殘酷的；駭人聽聞的

monstrous.eg: The illustrations show monstrous beasts with bodies like bears and heads like tigers.

month.eng_def: a period of about four weeks, especially one of the twelve periods into which a year is divided
month.eg: I'll be away for a month from mid-June to mid-July.

monthly.eng_def: happening or produced once a month
monthly.chi_def: 每月（的）；每月一次（的）；按月（的）

monthly.eng_def: a magazine that is published once a month

monument.eng_def: a structure or building that is built to honour a special person or event
monument.eg: In the square in front of the hotel stands a monument to all the people killed in the war.

monument.eng_def: an old building or place that is an important part of a country's history
monument.eg: Parts of the Berlin wall are being allowed to stand as historic monuments.

mood.eng_def: the way you feel at a particular time
mood.chi_def: 心境，心情，情緒；精神狀態

moon.eng_def: the round object that moves in the sky around the earth and can be seen at night
moon.eg: What time does the moon rise/set (= appear/disappear in the sky)?

moon.eng_def: the shape made by the amount of the moon that you can see at a particular time
moon.eg: There's no moon (= you cannot see the moon) tonight.

moon.eng_def: a similar round object that moves around another planet
to show your naked bottom in public, as a joke or as a protest
moon.chi_def: （為開玩笑或抗議，在公共場合）亮出光屁股
moon.eg: Two male juveniles were arrested and charged with indecent exposure after they mooned a police officer.

mop.eng_def: a stick with soft material attached to one end, especially used for washing floors
to use a mop to wash something
to use a cloth to remove sweat from the face
mop.eg: He kept pausing to mop his brow.

moral.eng_def: relating to the standards of good or bad behaviour, fairness, honesty, etc. that each person believes in, rather than to laws
moral.eg: It's her moral obligation to tell the police what she knows.

moral.eng_def: behaving in ways considered by most people to be correct and honest
standards for good or bad character and behaviour
The moral of a story, event, or experience is the message that you understand from it about how you should or should not behave
moral.eg: And the moral of the story is that honesty is always the best policy.

morale.eng_def: the amount of confidence felt by a person or group of people, especially when in a dangerous or difficult situation
morale.chi_def: （尤指險境或困境下的）士氣，精神面貌
morale.eg: A couple of victories would improve the team's morale enormously.

morality.eng_def: a set of personal or social standards for good or bad behaviour and character
morality.eg: They argued for a new morality based on self-sacrifice and honesty.

morality.eng_def: the quality of being right, honest, or acceptable
morality.eg: I have to question the morality of forcing poor people to pay for their medical treatment.

more.eng_def: a larger or extra number or amount
more.eg: Would you like some more food?

more.eng_def: used to form the comparative of many adjectives and adverbs
more.chi_def: （用以構成形容詞和副詞的比較級）更

more.eng_def: used to emphasize the large size of something
more.chi_def: （用於強調規模大）更大程度地，更大範圍內
more.eg: More than 20,000 demonstrators crowded into the square.
It gets more and more difficult to understand what is going on.

more.eng_def: used to say that when an action or event continues, there will be a particular result
more.eg: The more he drank, the more violent he became.

moreover.eng_def: (used to add information) also and more importantly
moreover.eg: The whole report is badly written. Moreover, it's inaccurate.

morning.eng_def: the part of the day from the time when the sun rises or you wake up until the middle of the day or lunch time
during the early part of the day
morning.eg: I listen to the radio in the morning.

morning.eng_def: at some time between twelve o'clock at night and twelve o'clock in the middle of the day
morning.eg: The murder took place at four in the morning.
She said she would see you in the morning.

morning.eng_def: a friendly way of greeting people when you meet them in the morning
morning.eg: Morning, Sue! How are you today?

mortal.eng_def: (of living things, especially people) unable to continue living for ever; having to die
extreme anxiety about or fear of someone or something
mortal.eg: We live in mortal dread of further attacks.

mortal.eng_def: a very serious and dangerous enemy, danger, threat, etc.
mortal.chi_def: 死敵／致命的危險／嚴重的威脅

mortal.eng_def: an ordinary person, rather than a god or a special, important, or powerful person
mortal.eg: The police officers guarding the door let in the celebrities, but they prevented us lesser/mere mortals from going inside.

mosquito.eng_def: a small flying insect that bites people and animals and sucks their blood
mosquito.eg: Some types of mosquito transmit malaria to humans.

moss.eng_def: a very small, green or yellow plant that grows especially in wet earth or on rocks, walls, and tree trunks
moss.eg: The rocks near the river were covered with moss.

most.eng_def: the biggest number or amount of; more than anything or anyone else
most.eg: What's the most you've ever won at poker?

most.eng_def: used to form the superlative of many adjectives and adverbs
most.chi_def: （用於構成許多形容詞和副詞的最高級）最
most.eg: Joanne is the most intelligent person I know.

most.chi_def: 大多數（的），大部分（的）；幾乎全部（的）
most.eg: I don't eat meat, but I like most types of fish.
It was a most beautiful morning.
You'll find her in the bar most every evening about six o'clock.

most.eng_def: used when saying what is the largest possible amount or number
most.eg: At most, the work will take a week.

most.eng_def: to take full advantage of something because it may not last long
most.eg: It's a beautiful day - we should make the most of it.
Dunnet Head is the northernmost part of the British mainland (= the part that is farther to the north than any other part).

mostly.eg: In the smaller towns, it's mostly (= usually) very quiet at nights.

motel.eng_def: a hotel for people travelling by car, usually with spaces for cars next to each room

moth.eng_def: an insect with wings that is similar to a butterfly, usually flies at night, and is attracted to light
moth.eg: Some types of moth eat holes in clothes.

mother.eg: My mother was 21 when she got married.

mother.eng_def: the title of a woman who is in charge of, or who has a high rank within, a convent (= house of religious women)
mother.chi_def: （對女修道院院長或較高職位修女的稱呼）
不要臉的傢伙，混賬東西（同 motherfucker）

mother.eng_def: to treat a person with great kindness and love and to try to protect them from anything dangerous or difficult
mother.eg: Stop mothering her - she's 40 years old and can take care of herself.

motherhood.eng_def: the state or time of being a mother
motherhood.eg: I don't feel ready for motherhood yet.

motion.eng_def: the act or process of moving, or a particular action or movement
motion.eg: The violent motion of the ship upset his stomach.

motion.eng_def: a polite way of referring to the process of getting rid of solid waste from the body, or the waste itself
motion.eg: The nurse asked if her motions were regular.

motion.eng_def: a formal suggestion made, discussed, and voted on at a meeting
motion.chi_def: （會議中正式提出準備表決的）提議，動議
motion.eg: Someone proposed a motion to increase the membership fee to $500 a year.

motion.eng_def: to make a signal to someone, usually with your hand or head
motion.eg: I saw him motion to the man at the door, who quietly left.

motivate.eng_def: to cause someone to behave in a particular way
motivate.eg: Like so many people, he's motivated by greed.

motivate.eng_def: to make someone want to do something well
motivate.eg: Teaching is all about motivating people to learn.

motivation.eg: He's a bright enough student - he just lacks motivation.

motivation.eng_def: the need or reason for doing something
motivation.eg: What was the motivation for the attack?

motive.eg: Why would she have killed him? She has no motive.

motive.eng_def: (of power or force) causing movement or action

motor.eng_def: a device that changes electricity or fuel into movement and makes a machine work
motor.chi_def: 發動機，引擎；電動機，馬達
motor.eg: The pump is powered by a small electric motor.
Do you know anyone who's looking for a second-hand motor?

motor.eng_def: connected with cars or other vehicles that have engines and use roads
motor.eg: This has been a difficult year for the motor industry/trade.

motor.eng_def: relating to muscles that produce movement, or the nerves and parts of the brain that control these muscles
motor.chi_def: 肌肉運動的；運動神經的

motor.eng_def: to move or increase very quickly
motor.eg: Shares have motored ahead as profits have risen.
I was just motoring along, minding my own business, when suddenly I was stopped by the police.

motorcycle.eng_def: a vehicle with two wheels and an engine

motto.eng_def: a short sentence or phrase that expresses a belief or purpose
motto.eg: Her motto is "Work hard, play hard".

mound.eng_def: a large pile of earth, stones, etc. like a small hill
mound.eg: a burial mound (= a place where people were buried in ancient times)

mound.eng_def: the raised area in baseball from which the pitcher throws the ball
mound.chi_def: （棒球場內高出地面的）投球區土墩

mount.eng_def: to gradually increase, rise, or get bigger
mount.eg: The children's excitement is mounting as Christmas gets nearer.

mount.eng_def: to get on a horse, bicycle, etc.. in order to ride
mount.eg: She mounted her horse and rode off.
He mounted the platform and began to speak to the assembled crowd.

mount.eng_def: to organize and begin an activity or event
to fix something to a wall, in a frame, etc., so that it can be looked at or used
mount.eg: The children's work has been mounted on coloured paper and put up on the walls of the classroom.
Sentries are mounted outside the palace at all times.
Armed security officers are employed to mount guard over the president.
an excellent mount for a child

mount.eng_def: something, such as a piece of card, that you put something on to show it
mount.chi_def: 底板，托板；裝幀，襯托紙，框
mount.eg: A black mount for this picture would look good.

mount.eng_def: used as part of the name of a mountain

mountain.eng_def: a raised part of the earth's surface, much larger than a hill, the top of which might be covered in snow
mountain.eg: The Matterhorn is one of the biggest mountains in Europe.
I've got a mountain of work to do.

mountain.eng_def: a large amount of food that is stored instead of being sold, so that prices for it do not fall

mourn.eng_def: to feel or express great sadness, especially because of someone's death
mourn.chi_def: （尤指因某人的亡故而）哀悼，悲傷
mourn.eg: Queen Victoria mourned Prince Albert/Prince Albert's death for 40 years.

mouse.eng_def: a small mammal with short fur, a pointed face, and a long tail
a small device that you move across a surface in order to move a cursor on your computer screen

mouth.eng_def: the opening in the face of a person or animal, consisting of the lips and the space between them, or the space behind containing the teeth and the tongue
mouth.eg: Open your mouth wide and say "Ah".

mouth.eng_def: the opening of a narrow container, the opening of a hole or cave, or the place where a river flows into the sea
mouth.chi_def: （容器的）口；洞口；（江河的）入海口
mouth.eg: Quebec is at the mouth of the St Lawrence River.

mouth.eng_def: to form words with the lips without making any sound
mouth.chi_def: 用口型默示；對口型假唱
mouth.eg: It looks to me as if the singers are only mouthing the words .

mouth.eng_def: to say something in a way that is not sincere
mouth.eg: I don't want to stand here listening to you mouthing apologies.

mouthpiece.eng_def: the part of a phone, musical instrument, or other device that goes near or between the lips
mouthpiece.chi_def: （電話的）送話口，話筒；（樂器的）吹口
mouthpiece.eg: To play the recorder, blow gently into the mouthpiece.

mouthpiece.eng_def: a person or a newspaper that only expresses the opinions of one particular organization
mouthpiece.eg: This newspaper is just a Republican mouthpiece.

move.eg: I'm so cold I can't move my fingers.

move.eng_def: to change the position of one of the pieces used in a board game
move.chi_def: （棋類遊戲中）走棋，走子，（棋子）被移動
move.eg: In chess, the pieces can only move in certain directions.

move.eng_def: to go to a different place to live or work
to leave your home in order to live in a new one
to (cause to) progress, change, or happen in a particular way or direction
move.eg: The judge's decision will allow the case to move forward.

move.eng_def: to cause someone to take action
move.eg: I can't imagine what could have moved him to say such a thing.

move.eng_def: to (cause to) change an opinion or the way in which you live or work
move.eg: He's made up his mind, and nothing you can say will move him on the issue.

move.eng_def: to cause someone to have strong feelings, such as sadness, sympathy, happiness, or admiration
move.eg: She said that she was deeply moved by all the letters of sympathy she had received.
No one wants to buy these toys - we just can't move them.
She moves in/among a very small circle of people.

move.eng_def: to suggest something, especially formally at a meeting or in a law court
move.chi_def: （在會議上）提出；提議；（向法庭）提出請求，申請
move.eg: A vote was just about to be taken when someone stood up and said that they wished to move an amendment.

move.eng_def: (used especially by doctors and nurses) to pass the contents of the bowels out of the body
move.chi_def: （尤為醫護人員用語）（使）（腸道）排泄糞便
move.eg: The doctor asked him if he'd moved his bowels that day.
She held the gun to his head and said, "One move and you're dead!"

move.eng_def: in some board games, a change of the position of one of the pieces used to play the game, or a change of position that is allowed by the rules, or a player's turn to move their piece
move.chi_def: 一步棋；（按規則）棋子的可走方法
move.eg: It takes a long time to learn all the moves in chess.

move.eng_def: an occasion when you go to live or work in a different place
move.eg: We've had four moves in three years.

move.eng_def: an action taken to achieve something
move.eg: Buying those shares was a good move.

move.eng_def: to be the first to take action
move.eg: Neither side seems prepared to make the first move towards reaching a peace agreement.

move.eng_def: to start a romantic or sexual relationship with someone
move.eg: She's liked him for a long time, but doesn't want to make the first move.

movement.eg: He made a sudden movement and frightened the bird away.

movement.eng_def: what someone is doing during a particular period
movement.eg: I don't know his movements this week.

movement.eng_def: a group of people with a particular set of aims
a situation in which people change their opinion or the way that they live or work
movement.chi_def: （意見、生活或工作模式的）改變
movement.eg: There has been a movement towards more women going back to work while their children are still young.

movement.eng_def: an occasion when something develops, changes, or happens in a particular way or direction
movement.chi_def: （按照一定方式或趨勢的）發展，改變
movement.eg: There has been little movement in the dollar (= it has not changed in value very much) today.

movement.eng_def: one of the main parts of a piece of classical music
movement.eg: Beethoven's fifth symphony has four movements.

movement.eng_def: the part of a clock or watch that turns the hands (= thin sticks) that point to the time
(used especially by doctors and nurses) an act of emptying the bowels
movement.chi_def: （尤為醫護人員用語）排泄糞便
movement.eg: When did you last have a (bowel) movement?

movie.eng_def: a film shown in a cinema or on television and often telling a story
a cinema or group of cinemas
movie.eg: What's on/showing at the movies this week?
She has worked in the movies all her life.

mow.eng_def: to cut plants, such as grass or wheat, that have long, thin stems and grow close together
mow.eg: You can't mow the grass/lawn if it's wet.

much.eng_def: a large amount or to a large degree
a far larger amount of something than you want or need
much.eg: You've drunk much too much to drive.

much.eng_def: more than someone can deal with
much.eg: I can't take care of six children at my age - it's too much.
I think it's a bit much for you to expect me to do all the cleaning.

much.eng_def: used at the end of a sentence to emphasize what you have just said
much.chi_def: （用在否定句末表示相反的意思）
much.eg: When he saw all the food on my plate, he said "Hungry much?"

much.chi_def: 優秀的事物；了不起，十分出色
much.eg: He's not much to look at, but he has a wonderful personality.

mud.eng_def: earth that has been mixed with water
mud.eg: The vehicles got bogged down in the heavy mud.

muddy.eng_def: covered by or containing mud (= wet, sticky earth)
muddy.chi_def: 泥濘的；渾濁的；黏滿爛泥的
muddy.eg: Don't bring those muddy boots inside!

muddy.eng_def: Muddy colours are dark and not bright.
muddy.eg: The room has been painted in muddy browns and greens.

muddy.eng_def: to put mud (= wet, sticky earth) into something or cover something with mud
muddy.eg: Industrial activity has muddied the river.

mudslide.eng_def: a mass of mud (= wet earth) moving suddenly and quickly down a steep slope

mug.eng_def: a large cup with straight sides used for hot drinks
mug.eg: I made myself a large mug of cocoa (= enough to fill a mug) and went to bed.

mug.eng_def: a heavy glass with a handle and usually with patterns cut into its side, out of which you drink beer
mug.chi_def: 啤酒杯（有柄且通常刻有花紋的大玻璃杯）

mug.eng_def: a person who is stupid and easily deceived
mug.eg: He's such a mug, he believes everything she tells him.

mug.eng_def: to attack a person in a public place and steal their money
mug.eg: He was mugged in broad daylight.

mule.eng_def: an animal whose mother is a horse and whose father is a donkey, used especially for transporting goods
a person who agrees to carry illegal drugs into another country in return for payment by the person selling the drugs
mule.chi_def: 毒品走私犯，越境運毒者
mule.eg: These very poor women who are used as mules by drug barons often get long prison sentences.

mule.eng_def: a woman's shoe or slipper that has no back

multiple.eng_def: very many of the same type, or of different types
multiple.eg: The young man died of multiple burns.

multiple.eng_def: a number that can be divided by a smaller number an exact number of times
multiple.eg: 18 is a multiple of 3, because 18 = 3 x 6.

multiple.eng_def: a large company that has shops in many towns

multiply.eng_def: to increase very much in number, or (in mathematics) to add a number to itself a particular number of times
multiply.eg: In warm weather these germs multiply rapidly.

mumble.eng_def: to speak quietly and in a way that is not clear so that the words are difficult to understand
mumble.eg: She mumbled something about being too busy.

mummy.eg: I want to go home, Mummy.

mummy.eng_def: (especially in ancient Egypt) a dead body that is prevented from decaying by being treated with special substances before being wrapped in cloth

murderer.eng_def: someone who illegally and intentionally kills another person
murderer.eg: A convicted murderer was executed in North Carolina yesterday.

muscular.eg: It was a muscular, hard-hitting documentary.

muse.eng_def: to think about something carefully and for a long time
muse.eg: I began to muse about/on the possibility of starting my own business.

muse.eng_def: an imaginary being, person, or force that gives someone ideas and helps them to write, paint, or make music
muse.chi_def: （寫作、繪畫或音樂創作方面的）靈感（泉源）
muse.eg: The muse has left me - I haven't written any poetry for months!

muse.eng_def: in ancient Greek and Roman stories, one of the nine goddesses who were believed to give encouragement in different areas of literature, art, and music
muse.chi_def: 繆斯（古希臘和羅馬神話中司文學、藝術和音樂的九位女神之一）

museum.eng_def: a building where objects of historical, scientific, or artistic interest are kept

mushroom.eng_def: a  fungus  with a round top and short stem. Some types of mushroom can be eaten

mushroom.eg: The number of computers in schools has mushroomed in recent years.

music.eng_def: a pattern of sounds made by musical instruments, voices, or computers, or a combination of these, intended to give pleasure to people listening to it
the art or study of music
the written system of symbols representing musical notes

musical.eng_def: related to or connected with music
If you are musical, you have a skill in or a great liking for music.
musical.chi_def: 有音樂天賦的；愛好音樂的
musical.eg: Joe's family all play instruments - they're very musical.

musical.eng_def: a play or film in which part of the story is sung to music

musician.eng_def: someone who is skilled in playing music, usually as a job
musician.eg: The concert features dancers and musicians of all nationalities.

must.eng_def: used to show that it is necessary or very important that something happens in the present or future
If you say that you must do something, you mean that you strongly intend to do something in the future.

must.eg: I must say, you look absolutely great.

must.eng_def: If you tell someone else that they must do something pleasant, you are emphasizing that you think it is a good idea to do that.
must.eg: You must come and stay with us one weekend.

must.eng_def: used to show that something is very likely, probable, or certain to be true
must.eg: Harry's been driving all day - he must be tired.
If you live in the country a car is a must.

must.eng_def: something that is so good, you must do it, have it, or see it
must.eg: The cashmere scarf is this season's must-have.

mustache.eng_def: US spelling of  moustache mainly UK

mustard.eng_def: a thick yellow or brown sauce that tastes spicy and is eaten cold in small amounts, especially with meat

mute.eg: The president has remained mute about plans to curtail the number of immigrants.

mute.eng_def: a device for changing the sound of a musical instrument, usually making it quieter
mute.eg: He was playing his trumpet with a mute.

mute.eng_def: a button on an electronic device that makes it silent
mute.eg: I pressed the mute on my phone so she couldn't hear the people talking in the background.

mute.eng_def: a person who is not able to speak
If you mute a noise, you do something to make it less loud.
mute.eg: Heavy curtains muted the noise of the traffic.

mute.eng_def: If you mute a musical instrument, you attach a device to it that changes its sound, usually making it quieter.

mutter.eng_def: to speak quietly and in a low voice that is not easy to hear, often when you are worried or complaining about something
(the sound of) words being said very quietly
mutter.eg: I heard the soft mutter of voices in the next room.

mutter.eng_def: a complaint that is made to only a few people
mutter.eg: There were mutters that other departments received more money than ours.

mutton.eng_def: the meat from an adult sheep eaten as food
the meat from a goat or sheep eaten as food

mutual.eng_def: (of two or more people or groups) feeling the same emotion, or doing the same thing to or for each other
mutual.chi_def: 相互的，彼此的；共同的，共有的
mutual.eg: Theirs was a partnership based on mutual respect, trust and understanding.

mutual.eng_def: a financial organization that is owned by its members, rather than by shareholders
mutual.chi_def: 互惠機構（由成員而不是持股人擁有的金融機構）

mysterious.eng_def: strange, not known, or not understood
mysterious.chi_def: 神秘的事物，難以理解的事物，謎
mysterious.eg: She's an actress whose inner life has remained mysterious, despite the many interviews she has given.

mystery.eng_def: something strange or not known that has not yet been explained or understood
mystery.chi_def: 神秘的事物，難以理解的事物，謎
mystery.eg: How the massive stones were brought here from hundreds of miles away is/remains a mystery.

mystery.eng_def: a book, film, or play, especially about a crime or a murder, with a surprise ending that explains all the strange events that have happened
mystery.chi_def: 懸疑作品；懸疑電影；推理劇

myth.eng_def: an ancient story or set of stories, especially explaining the early history of a group of people or about natural events and facts
a commonly believed but false idea
myth.chi_def: 普遍但卻錯誤的看法，無根據的觀念
myth.eg: Statistics disprove the myth that women are worse drivers than men.

mythology.eg: She's fascinated by the stories of classical mythology (= ancient Greek and Roman myths).

mythology.eng_def: a popular belief that is probably not true
mythology.eg: It's just a piece of popular mythology that people always get sacked when they are away from the office.

nag.eng_def: to criticize or complain often in an annoying way
nag.chi_def: 不斷批評（或抱怨）；跟…糾纏不休；嘮叨
nag.eg: My mum's always nagging me to get my hair cut.

nag.eng_def: a horse, especially one that is too old to be useful

nail.eng_def: a small, thin piece of metal with one pointed end and one flat end that you hit into something with a hammer, especially in order to fasten or join it to something else
a thin, hard area that covers the upper side of the end of each finger and each toe

nail.eg: She had nailed a small shelf to the door.

nail.eng_def: to catch someone, especially when they are doing something wrong, or to make it clear that they are guilty
nail.chi_def: （尤指當場）抓獲，逮住；證明…有罪，揭發
nail.eg: The police had been trying to nail those guys for months.

naive.eng_def: too willing to believe that someone is telling the truth, that people's intentions in general are good, or that life is simple and fair. People are often naive because they are young and/or have not had much experience of life
naive.eg: She was very naive to believe that he'd stay with her.

naked.eng_def: Something that is naked does not have its usual covering.
naked.eg: a naked flame/light bulb (= one with nothing surrounding or covering it)

naked.eng_def: A naked feeling or quality is not hidden, although it is bad.
naked.chi_def: （感覺或特質）毫不掩飾的，顯而易見的，赤裸裸的

name.eng_def: the word or words that a person, thing, or place is known by
the opinion or reputation that someone or something has
name.eg: She went to court to clear her name (= prove that the bad things said about her were not true).

name.eng_def: someone who is famous or has a good reputation
name.eg: It seemed like all the big names in football were there.
I need to talk to a professor by the name of Bin Said.

name.eng_def: to give yourself a name that is not your real name
name.eg: In the business world he goes by the name of J. Walter Fortune.

name.eng_def: for someone or belonging to someone
name.chi_def: 以（某人）的名義；在（某人）名下
name.eg: I'm here to pick up my tickets - I reserved them by phone yesterday in the name of Tremin.

name.eng_def: to give someone or something a name
name.eg: We named our dogs Shandy and Belle.

name.eng_def: to say what something or someone's name is
name.eg: In the first question you had to name three types of monkey.
Just name the time and I'll be there.

namely.eng_def: used when you want to give more detail or be more exact about something you have just said
namely.eg: We need to get more teachers into the classrooms where they're most needed, namely in high poverty areas.

nanny.eng_def: a woman whose job is to take care of a particular family's children

nanny.eg: Can I have a drink, Nanny?

nap.eng_def: a short sleep, especially during the day
nap.eg: Grandpa usually has/takes a nap after lunch.

nap.eng_def: the surface of a piece of cloth such as velvet, consisting of short threads that have been brushed in one direction
to sleep for a short time, especially during the day
nap.eg: He likes to nap for an hour when he gets home from work.
